Award.AwardTitle: Engaged student learning - Exploration and Design: Small group learning in engineering systems and control education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative learning is based on the view that knowledge is a social construct. Research shows that educational experiences that are active and social lead to deeper learning, higher level thinking and an increase in understanding of diverse perspectives. The Small Group Learning in Engineering Systems and Control Education project addresses barriers to the adoption of collaborative learning methods by engineering instructors through the development of small group learning activities and associated instructional materials. The learning activities will be developed collectively by a faculty from diverse institutions of higher education. The intellectual merit of this project is threefold: it develops small-group classroom activities that enable students to visualize abstract concepts; it conducts a cross-sectional case study and provides associated data for several colleges and universities that allows us to study educational outcomes of small-group learning in the engineering classroom; and it identifies and addresses the problems that instructors face regarding limited resources and time required to revamp classroom pedagogy.

The project will develop and disseminate classroom instructional activities that complement didactic instruction through workshops, evaluation of activities over course offerings across many different colleges and universities by faculty participants, assessing outcomes, and planning for broader dissemination of approaches through the engineering curriculum. Workshop participants are engineering faculty representing colleges and universities whose undergraduate programs serve and include a mix of traditional students, non-traditional students (older students with families and jobs), underrepresented minorities, women, or students who plan to enter military service. As such, the activities and outcomes will impact a large cross-section of students through the engineering education offered by these colleges. Materials developed through project activities will be disseminated as open-source documents, designs, instructions, videos, and lesson plans for using small group activities within the classroom to generate impact beyond the participants' institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This Engaged Student Learning: Exploration project addressed barriers to widespread adoption of collaborative learning by engineering instructors.  This goal was accomplished by collaborative development of small group learning activities and associated instructional material for use in the classroom, and a shared electronic workspace for distribution and maintenance of the materials.  The key hypothesis evaluated was that many faculty, working collaboratively, can address issues of time, resource needs, and effectiveness of activities for active learning in the classroom. As an exploration project, objectives sought to 1) collaboratively develop learning activities for systems and control courses with engineering faculty from diverse institutions of higher education, 2) use the activities in the classroom for two years, measure learning outcomes, and 3) disseminate activities and findings with a broader community of engineering educators.

The objectives were achieved through a combination of development of instructional materials for systems and dynamics classroom teaching in undergraduate engineering curricula and a faculty workshop. Dartmouth College hosted the workshop in 2017 to develop materials collectively and distributed the materials to a user group of workshop participants. The materials developed include the Fidget car - a relatively low cost, open-source apparatus developed at Dartmouth College. A suite of small group activities for systems and control theory classes were developed around the Fidget Car by faculty from diverse institutions of higher education for systems and control education. Participants from both large state universities and small undergraduate-only colleges worked collaboratively to develop the activities. The user group used the materials during the 2017-18 academic year and 2018-19 academic year (two years) encompassing one to two course offerings per year per participant.  Following participation in two annual conferences, we recruited additional users who did not participate in the workshop and these users implemented one or more of the learning activities during the 2019-20 academic year.   Of the eight activities developed in the workshop, faculty participants implemented two to six activities in each course offering, with several faculty participants using activities in more than one course. We delivered 110 Fidget Cars by fall 2019.  70 were distributed to workshop participants, and an additional 40 cars were distributed to faculty recruited at conferences.

Broader Impacts: The activities developed enable students across all types of institutions of higher education to develop intuition about systems theory, motivate the mathematical concepts typically covered in a control theory class through discovery-oriented procedures, and provides hands-on experience with control hardware.  Some participants used the cars as a means of providing relevant virtual classroom activities during COVID-19 transition to online instruction in the spring of 2020.  Another instructor modified the original Fidget car using OEM parts for wider distribution and use for online ?hands-on? instruction.

A Google site was developed to aid in adoption of activities by classroom instructors. Publications provide details on construction and operation of the Fidget Car, on learning activities developed, and on initial outcomes.

Two forms of assessment were conducted - student assessments for each learning activity and faculty assessments to evaluate the effectiveness of collaborative development of activities by groups of faculty on adoption within time and resource constraints that each faculty member experiences in their institution. Assessment data show that collaborative development overcame several significant barriers to adoption of learning activities for the classroom, and our student assessment data provide substantial evidence that small-group learning activities are effective in engaging students in core systems concepts.
